context.text: Keeping that in mind, a recommendation is made for a suitable model to use for future, more detailed study that is based on work done by [1], [2].

The model done in [1], [2] is comprehensive enough to take into account several factors such as channel fading and shadowing, power control, spot beam antenna gains and imperfections across the cell region.

The number of users for a capacity limited channel is given [1], [2], [4]–[7]: 


•
nTDMAtotal TDMA capacity (users)


•

•
Nsb is the total number of spot beams (equal to total area of the united states divided by one cell area).


•
Ncis the total number of carriers available.


•
\$\zeta_{{\rm ru}}\$ is the frequency reuse factor.


•
\$\zeta_{{\rm p}}\$ is the polarization factor


•
\$\mu\$ is the Frame efficiency (per frame):


•
\$\mu=1-(overhead{\_}bits/total{\_}bits)\$


•
RTDMAthe TDMA output rate (b/s) which will also depend on the modulation scheme or the number of bits each modulation symbol represent, and is given by:


•
\$R_{TDMA}=m.

The CDMA model on the other hand was based on the following [1], [2], [4]–[7]:
 where the parameters are as defined previously in addition to:


•
nCDMAtotal CDMA capacity (users)


•
BWtotaltotal available BW (Hz)


•
\$\zeta_{{\rm sh}}\$ is a factor that takes into account soft hand off within each cell with neighbor cells


•
Eb/No is the required energy per bit over noise Spectral density


•
\$\zeta_{\rm oc}\$ is out of cell interference factor (equal to out of cell power per one user normalized by in cell desired power setting)


•
\$\alpha\$ is the voice activity index per user


•
\$\sigma\$ is the standard deviation of the power control algorithm error in db

.

Note that IS95 utilizes a 0.4 factor while studies done in [1], [2] show that the value is as large as approximately 2 for a LEO satellite constellation with spot beams servicing mobile users on ground.
Next, a more common comparison is shown (Figure 6), using parameters from the Iridium system in order to compare results here to other results found in [1].
This result matches with that stated in [1].

For the CDMA part, at the same 8 kb/s one gets approximately 180 users which is also close to the values found in [1], [2] but with perfect power control in [1], [2] as oppose to the 2 db error in the model used here.
In [1] it is found that for every 1 db increase in power control error, there is a 30% reduction in capacity of CDMA systems.
In this study (as oppose to that in [1]) a lower reduction due to power control error is seen (about 10% to 15%) using the models shown in the previous sections.
That also assumes the ability to keep a small power control error (based on [1]).
Next, it is worth noting that the model developed in [1], [2] is in the author's opinion a best available model for a detailed type of analyses (if found necessary) for the AMSS.

In summary if the AMSS usage and the required data rates turn out to give requirements that are close to the limits shown by the plots in the write up, then it is warranted to do additional detailed analyses utilizing accordingly more detailed models such as the one in [1], [2].
The additional features of the model in [1], [2] where mentioned in the introduction and results sections.
Finally it may be possible to further verify those comparison type models (the one here to that in [1], [2]) via modeling and simulations.

As previously stated, models done in [2] are more detailed in that they include many additional factors such as adjacent channel interference, link parameters such as gains of antenna and noise power, Doppler shifts, intermodulation noise, Racian fading, and C/No for uplink and downlink combined.
The model done in [2] was for a C band uplink, with L band downlink where 4 Mhz is allocated for a Mobile Satellite Service for coverage over Asia.

Again assuming the use of parameters in Table one, the differences are as follows:


•

The actual outside cell interference as actually small (about 0.08) in this case per [2].

In general those factors have less of an effect than the ones discussed here, except for the adjacent channel interference and total noise power over total received transponder power with both having an effect of up to 1 db per [2] scenarios (included in Figure 7 case).
Next, it is worth noting that the model developed in [1], [2] is in the author's opinion a best available model for a detailed type of analyses (if found necessary) for the AMSS.

In summary if the AMSS usage and the required data rates turn out to give requirements that are close to the limits shown by the plots in the write up, then it is warranted to do additional detailed analyses utilizing accordingly more detailed models such as the one in [1], [2].
The additional features of the model in [1], [2] where mentioned in the introduction and results sections.
Finally it may be possible to further verify those comparison type models (the one here to that in [1], [2]) via modeling and simulations.

context.text: In [7], the pursuit–evasion game and map-building problems are combined in a single probabilistic framework.

Since the dependence of \$E_{\overline{g}} [{\bf{T}}^\ast]\$ on the pursuit policy \$\overline{g}\$ is, in general, very complex [7], instead of finding the optimal policy that minimizes \$E_{\overline{g}}[{\bf{T}}^\ast]\$, we look for efficiently computable suboptimal policies with good performance.
To this end, we first introduce the notion of a persistent pursuit policy [7] and show that it guarantees a certain degree of success for the pursuers.

context.text: Recent longterm experiments with autonomous robots [1]–[3] have shown that an impressively high level of reliability and autonomy can be reached by explicitly representing and maintaining the uncertainty inherent in the available information.

Successful state estimation systems have been implemented for a variety of tasks including the estimation of the robot's position in a known environment [5], the automatic learning of environment maps, the state estimation for objects with dynamic states (such as doors), for the tracking of people locations [6], [7], and gesture recognition [1].

context.text: In this centralized approach, the motion of the group is described in an \$N \times M\$-dimensional space and can be estimated by applying Kalman filtering techniques [28], [32].

Kalman filter estimation can be divided into two cycles [32]: a) the propagation cycle, where knowledge about the state of the system is propagated to the next (time) step, based on the assumptions about the evolution of the system equations, the measured control inputs, and the statistical description of the system noise, and b) the update cycle, where relative pose measurements are processed to update the propagated estimates calculated during the previous cycle.

The former category is characterized by minimalism and robustness but a lack of guarantees that the desired formation will actually emerge; the latter category is characterized by reliability and efficiency but also a need for global knowledge and computation. This is reasonable, given that the problem of aggregating robots into such a configuration has already been empirically demonstrated [11], and it is possible through only local interaction to have \$N\$ robots form a chain [17].

A system is connectively stable if it is stable in the sense of Liapunov for all possible \$E = ({e_{ij} })\$ [36].

For the system \${\bf S}\$ to be connectively stable, the following test matrix \$W=(w_{ij})\$ must be an M matrix (i.e., all leading principal minors must be positive) [36] where the symmetric positive definite matrix \$G_{i}\$ satisfies the Liapunov matrix equation \$A_{i}^{T} H_{i} + H_{i} A_{i} = - G_{i}\$ and \$\lambda _{m} (\bullet)\$ and \$\lambda _{M} (\bullet)\$ are the minimum and maximum eigenvalues of the corresponding matrices.
